text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with coconut cream french toast
that's right i don't know about you but
i like to make very realistic easy to
keep New Year's resolutions and one of
those for me this year is to raise my
brunch and breakfast game and that's
what inspired today's presentation is
we're going to be doing a coconut spike
version of classic french toast and by
the way do not let the name fool you I
know it sounds decadent and unhealthy
but in reality this is actually probably
better for you than the traditional
version so with that let's go ahead get
started and first up we're going to prep
the batter and for that let's crack 1
large egg into a mixing bowl to which we
will add 1 egg yolk sure you could
probably just put both whole eggs in
there but for me this comes out nicer
with a little higher yolk to white ratio
and then to our eggs we're going to need
to add some coconut milk which just in
case you haven't worked with before it
looks like this alright it comes in a
can and it kind of looks like heavy
cream and it has the most beautiful
subtly sweet coconut flavor so we will
add some of that to our eggs and then
continue on with the teaspoon of sugar
as well as a few drops of pure vanilla
extract and please do not substitute
impure and then last but not least we'll
also do a little touch of freshly grated
nutmeg and that's going to be it for
this very simple yet as you'll see very
effective batter and then all we need to
do is take a whisk and give that a mix
at which point that's ready to use to
soak our bread and what I like to use is
some stale at least a old French or
Italian bread that we've sliced about
1/2 inch to 3/4 inch thick and above and
beyond burning it the only way to screw
up french toast is to use not stale
bread ok if our breads not stale is not
going to soak in that batter like we
want so if you only remember one thing
from this video let it be this as we say
in the business if your breads not dry
your french toast ain't fly alright so
that is crucial but assuming you are
working with some nice stale fairly dry
bread we can go ahead and start dunking
that into our batter and how I like to
do this is give each slice a good
dunking and then I'll kind of pile those
up as I go dunking the next ones into
the batter at the bottom and then what
we'll do once those are all thoroughly
coated is let them sit there on the
counter giving them a toss every 2 to 3
minutes until the batter is pretty much
all absorbed
so we'll give a toss we'll let them sit
there for a few minutes and then we'll
give them another toss moving the wetter
ones from the bottom to the top and the
drier ones from the top to the bottom
and roughly I don't know 15 20 minutes
later this is what mine look like I
pretty much had full absorption and yes
if you want you could do this ahead in
the fridge in fact in the restaurant the
bread was so dry we used to soak those
the night before and then cook them the
next day but anyway once our nice stale
bread has fully absorbed our batter we
are ready to cook our coconut cream
french toast in a little bit of butter
okay just enough to coat the pan yes I'm
joking we want a ton of butter here and
we will melt that over medium heat and
we'll go ahead and transfer our bread in
and then once that's been accomplished
all we need to do is cook these on
medium for about I don't know five
minutes or so per side or until the
outside is nicely browned and kind of
crispy and the inside is cooked through
and by the way I'm guessing in five
minutes forget I even said that so the
exact time is going to be up to you as
you are the hosts of your french toast
so I don't want you paying too much
attention to the time I want you to go
by appearance and feel in common sense
so we will let that first side cook on
medium till we see a getting brown at
which point we can go ahead and flip
those over and believe it or not we will
do the exact same thing to the other
side but wait there's more once I have
both sides kind of brown I do like to
flip them back over so I'm really making
sure I'm getting a nice crust on both
sides and you might be thinking hey
isn't that extra flipping gonna cause it
to absorb more butter yes I hope so we
will continue cooking on medium until we
think those have gone long enough and
here's how I can tell the bread is
actually going to kind of spring back to
the touch okay if it feels mushy it's
probably not done so we want to feel it
spring back as well as we want it to
have formed a nice crispy surface which
we of course will test with a fork
because as you know Fork don't lie and
of course any time you're doing
something like this some are going to
finish before others so once a piece
finishes go ahead and remove it to a pan
and we could just keep those in a warm
oven and speaking of of and yes you can
just brown these and finish them all in
the oven but since these weren't too
thick I ended up just doing them right
in the pan and then once we've
determined those are all crispy and
cooked through we are ready to serve up
which I'm going to do of course on a
warm plate because I care about my
guests and then at this point you are
free to finish your coconut cream French
too
anyway you want but what follows is my
official survey suggestion which starts
with a generous drizzle of maple syrup
grade B of course oh yeah
grade B is the money SERP so we will
drizzle over some of that but not too
much because we have two more slightly
sweet garnishes the first two which
would be some freshly sliced mango and
the key with a fruit garnish like this
is that you want enough but you don't
want to put too much so try to put on
the perfect number of slices and then to
bring this all together what we'll do is
finish this up with some toasted coconut
which i think is going to look great and
tastes great but also provide a little
textural contrast and then last but not
least I garnished with a little wedge of
lime because that is so good with mango
and that's it our coconut cream french
toast is ready to enjoy and I really did
love this which is a little bit of a
surprise since I'm not into sweet
breakfast
not a huge french toast person plus
coconut is not my favorite thing but
despite all that I really did enjoy this
and no it doesn't really taste like a
coconut cream pie that name just sounded
better than coconut french toast but
while it's not really creamy and
decadent it still has the most wonderful
subtle sweet coconut flavor that is just
absolutely perfect with that tangy fruit
and toasted pieces of coconut as well as
the optional fresh lime juice which I
just remembered I put on the plate here
and that actually did make it even more
enjoyable so anyway that's it what I'm
calling coconut cream french toast like
I said one of my very attainable New
Year's resolutions was to up my
breakfast and brunch game a little bit
this year and I think this is a pretty
good start so I really do hope you give
this a try soon head over to food wishes
comm for all the ingredient amounts and
more info as usual and as always enjoy
you
[Music]
